title: My sexually abusive nStep-dad got arrested yesterday

author: WithoutAComma
text:
Great news! This choice to pursue justice/accountability for the abuse you experienced must have taken a lot of courage.

I hope this is part of a fruitful healing process for you, and that one day very soon you won't feel as though you have a ruined life.

author: thechickfromcalgary
text:
Thank you so much. I genuinely appreciate that.

My hope is to see him behind bars, never in a position to hurt other girls again.

Because of him, I have struggled with maintaining normal, healthy relationships. I can't have a full-time job because of the anxiety and depression his actions directly caused.

I have been in therapy for 6 years now, and I can feel myself growing and healing in every session. I genuinely hope that getting justice will help me continue the process.

I have a case worker who has supported me through this process, and she's encouraging me to write a book after all is said and done. I think that that will help me heal as well, to put my life on paper and share it with the world.

I want to let every victim of abuse know that they are strong, and they deserve justice. They deserve to be heard. Most of all, they deserve love and everything that their abusers have denied them.

author: WithoutAComma
text: You sound like you are really on the right path, that you are taking care of yourself and doing the best you can to make some positive meaning out of this. Making the world a better place for people who also experience abuse can be a beautiful way to rewrite your own story. You and your brother are also very fortunate to have each other! Do keep us posted!

author: thechickfromcalgary
text:
It's taken a long time to get on this right path! I'm so happy that it's coming through now.

I will absolutely keep y'all posted!

author: motie
text:
I really like your post. Thank you for posting it.

I thought I’d offer this perspective: Human pieces of shit who do things like your stepfather did/does are rare. I’m not saying they’re not real and I will say that even one of them existing is too many. But my point is that the vast majority of people aren’t like that. So I hope you’re able to find a high quality person to trust and love. And I’d say the odds are stacked heavily in your favor. Good luck to you.

author: thechickfromcalgary
text:
Thank you very much!

I actually started dating someone about 2 months ago who seems like one of the amazing ones so far. He's the only person my cats have ever adored the way they do (seriously, one of my cats likes my bf more than the cat likes me). Considering the fact that my cats are typically excellent judges of character, I'm taking this as a good sign.

author: Flock_with_me
text: This thread has been removed because it derails the OP.

author: LillytheFurkid
text: I have worked in the justice system with offenders like OP's step dad, men who move on to become scout leaders or get other positions of trust around children so they can access more kids. But that's a technicality, you clearly know better. Bygones.

author: Flock_with_me
text: This is really rude. Be kind and respectful to everyone here.

author: Flock_with_me
text:
This thread has been removed. A terrible act doesn't stop being terrible just because a certain time has passed. The hurt certainly doesn't just disappear, and the OP still needs to find a way to process it.

Generally, there can be a lot of valid reasons for not reporting something immediately. Not everyone can take action right away, but that certainly doesn't mean it's unfair to do so later.

author: thechickfromcalgary
text: To clarify: the last act of abuse occurred when i was 19. I was 21 when I reported, and 22 now. It has not been very long since he abused me.

author: Flock_with_me
text: Even if it had been long ago, it would still have been fine. I'm sorry you experienced that abuse at all, and very happy for you now.

author: thechickfromcalgary
text:
Thank you so much. I'm very happy that Canada removed the Statute of Limitations regarding sex crimes recently, so more victims from the past can come forward and bring their abusers and assaulters to justice.

Time passed does not matter. The trauma remains, and so does the need for closure and justice.
